message: Now that you're detecting/handling 'paste' style messages differently in the HTML UI, can you expose that metadata in the json too?
hmm... sounds good
not asking for the message body to be html formatted, asking for access to the data which defines paste vs not-paste
@protocool how does Campfire do their paste thing? maybe we could do something similar for our paste/code snippets?

@leah - I never even noticed that because I pull out embeddable urls from the original text myself... it's spooky how well that dovetails with Propane2's new "message accessories" pipeline (allows plugins to detect urls in the message and add their own accessory view. Standard inline messages are displayed with a built-in plugin).
ultimately it doesn't matter how you do it, as long as it doesn't prescribe HTML, require a second round-trip, and is settable when creating a message
and @leah, super stupid question probably, but what's embeds:[] ?
@protocool np. the inline images... I called it "embeds" in case we add other stuff later
right now it's just the images though
there's both the convore scaled-down secure version of the image url and the original
@protocool oh yeah, it's a separate message... hmmm..
@protocool yeah, I'll definitely pull out the snippets into their own thing... I need to chat with @ericflo to determine the edge cases but I'll get back to you :D
they define a specific message type of PasteMessage
ugh.... please no extra round trip for it tho :-)

and not to be a complete pain @leah but one thing my users use a *lot* is sending single lines as paste messages. It's useful for sending URLs that you don't want auto-expanded. That's one way that CF's different message types works well. The client selects the type explicitly rather than letting the server decide.
we still need to talk about it internally, sorry :\
np - not urgent for me, but getting there
'bump' is such a cheesy thing to do but.. well... *bump* :-)
sorry about the lack of response here

btw @ericflo I'm now sold on 'topics'. Much easier to resurrect an entire conversation thread than including a link in a message saying "remember when we talked about X here? What's happening on that?".
